title: NaN3 - 1 2 atm equil- double mass- 21 kJ released

content.question:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Sodium azide, <math alttext="N a N 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NaN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, is an ionic compound that can be synthesized from hydrazoic acid, <math alttext="H N 3, aqueous," overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, as represented by the net ionic equation below.

<math alttext="H N 3, aqueous, plus O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, react to produce, N 3 with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>l</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) The student believes this is an acid-base reaction and claims that <math alttext="H N 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are an acid-base conjugate pair. Do you agree or disagree with the claim that the two compounds are an acid-base conjugate pair? Justify your answer.

frqParts.text:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Sodium azide, <math alttext="N a N 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NaN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, is an ionic compound that can be synthesized from hydrazoic acid, <math alttext="H N 3, aqueous," overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, as represented by the net ionic equation below.

<math alttext="H N 3, aqueous, plus O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, react to produce, N 3 with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>l</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) The student believes this is an acid-base reaction and claims that <math alttext="H N 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are an acid-base conjugate pair. Do you agree or disagree with the claim that the two compounds are an acid-base conjugate pair? Justify your answer.

Two possible Lewis electron-dot diagrams and experimentally determined information for <math alttext="H N 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><msub><mrow><mtext>HN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> are shown below.

(b) Use <math alttext="V S E P R" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>VSEPR</mtext></mrow></math> theory to explain why Diagram 1 is consistent with the experimentally determined bond angles around <math alttext="N sub x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> shown above.
(c) Explain why Diagram 2 is NOT consistent with the experimentally determined bond lengths.

In a sealed, rigid and previously evacuated container, a solid sample of <math alttext="N a N 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><msub><mrow><mtext>NaN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> partially decomposes at <math alttext="323 Kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>323</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, creating a volume of <math alttext="75 liters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>75</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and an internal pressure of <math alttext="1.2 atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>1.2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. The decomposition reaction is represented by the equation below.
<math alttext="2 N a N 3, solid, is in equilibrium with, 2 N a, solid, plus 3 N 2, gas. K sub lowercase p, equals, open parenthesis, uppercase P, sub N 2, end sub, close parenthesis, cubed" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mtext> NaN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⇄</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> Na</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><msub><mrow><mtext> N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="2.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
(d) Use the information above to calculate the value of <math alttext="K sub lowercase p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) The student finds a reference where the chemical equation is written differently, which is shown below. Calculate the value of <math alttext="K sub lowercase p, prime," display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>′</mo></mrow></math> for the reaction represented by the equation shown below.
<math alttext="4 N a N 3, solid, is in equilibrium with, 4 N a, solid, plus 6 N 2, gas. K sub lowercase p, prime, equals question mark" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><msub><mrow><mtext> NaN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⇄</mo><mn>4</mn><mtext> Na</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><msub><mrow><mtext> N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="2.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>′</mo><mo>=</mo><mtext> </mtext><mo>?</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

(f) In a second experiment, the student runs the reaction under the same conditions using double the initial mass of <math alttext="N a N 3, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><msub><mrow><mtext>NaN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, but the volume of <math alttext="N a N 3, solid," display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><msub><mrow><mtext>NaN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is insignificant compared to that of the gas. The student predicts the <math alttext="K sub lowercase p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> value of the reaction will double in this experiment. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s prediction? Justify your answer.

(g) In a third experiment, the student collects the nitrogen gas in a flexible container. The gas occupies a volume of <math alttext="75 liters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>75</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> at a pressure of <math alttext="1.2 atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>1.2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. If the pressure is changed to <math alttext="2.4 atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>2.4</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> with no change in temperature, determine the final volume. Include units in your answer.

The enthalpy of reaction when <math alttext="N a N 3, solid," overflow="scroll"><mstyle><msub><mrow><mtext>NaN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> decomposes at <math alttext="298 Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>298</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown below.

<math alttext="2 N a N 3, solid, produces, 2 N a, solid, plus 3 N 2, gas. delta H naught, sub reaction, equals negative 42 kilojoules per mole, sub reaction, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>42</mn><mtext> kJ/</mtext><msub><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="monospace"><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

(h) A student claims that when <math alttext="1.0 mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a N 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><msub><mrow><mtext>NaN</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> is decomposed completely, <math alttext="21 kilojoules" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>21</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kJ</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> of energy is released into the surroundings. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer in terms of both the sign and magnitude of <math alttext="delta H naught of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 5.B: Identify an appropriate theory, definition, or mathematical relationship to solve a problem.
